instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4652: What is 820-4652? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesnâ€™t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PCH_INTVRMEN_L: What is PCH_INTVRMEN_L? PCH_INTVRMEN_L is a signal that stands for Internal Voltage Regulator Enable. When pulled high, this signal enables the internal 1.05 V regulators for the Suspend well in the PCH. This signal must be pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4652</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A iMac 27 not starting.
threads.message:
Hi, 


Got this iMac. First it was damaged power supply, then L7150 was completly burnt. Replace them bot and there were some lines with wrong componentes on it. Replaced and repaird all them and now i am getting LED 1 on. But still not booting machine. 



When try to boot pressing button led 1 turns off and turns on again. Checked Power lines for S5-S3 and seems all ok. 


I am not getting sys good because of missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>,  Checked SMC and seems to be ok. Anyway reballed it. Still not spinning fans.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4652</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A iMac 27 not starting.
threads.message:
Check <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> and all PCH's RTC signals.

Post <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_PCH_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> levels.
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> as same moment.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4652</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A iMac 27 not starting.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4652</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A iMac 27 not starting.
threads.message: Then check for high pulse at all <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals, at same time...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4652</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A iMac 27 not starting.
threads.message: will check it now. Do you know if CPU is dead will it do that with 1st led? Will i get sys power good if CPU is removed?

threads.message: PCH/CPU not involved in S5 state generation...

<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4652</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A iMac 27 not starting.
threads.message:
Is not the first time when I mention about these signals; 4 (four) in total, apart of 32KHz clock.
Look at <CHIP>U1100</CHIP> RTC block on page 11.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4652</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A iMac 27 not starting.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4652</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A iMac 27 not starting.
threads.message:
WHY?
Did you check mentioned signals?
These are inputs, required by PCH to start power on sequence...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4652</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A iMac 27 not starting.
threads.message: will check it on monday. thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4652</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A iMac 27 not starting.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4652</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A iMac 27 not starting.
threads.message:
There is separate PCH (<CHIP>U1100</CHIP>) and shouldn't be affected by L7150 overvoltage.
But if CPU (<CHIP>U0500</CHIP>) has been damaged this way, still exists a low "chance" it affected PCH too.

If you do NOT get at least a pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>, or <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> when trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>, that points to a bad PCH...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4652</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A iMac 27 not starting.
